instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.LVDS_DDC_DATA: What is LVDS_DDC_DATA? LVDS_DDC_DATA Is the DDC data line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .

threads.message:
[COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px]No LVDS-DP[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]  [COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px]No 1.5V going to GPU[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px] [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px]<CHIP>U9500</CHIP>: [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0GPU</SIGNAL> not present [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PP1V5_GPU_REG</SIGNAL> not present[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

  [COLOR=#222222][FONT=Arial][SIZE=13px] [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

Everything around it seems to be ok, I don't know what I'm missing[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message: Did you checked the VIN-Pin 6 or the resistor <RESISTOR>R9500</RESISTOR>?

threads.message: Have you tried giving heat to GPU????

threads.message:
[QUOTE="Crizz, post: 2850"]Did you checked the VIN-Pin 6 or the resistor <RESISTOR>R9500</RESISTOR>?[/QUOTE]
<RESISTOR>R9500</RESISTOR> is OK, VIN is-Pin6 is 12.25V

There is no point heating the GPU if it's not getting 1.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message:
actually aprendiz was asking if you tried to give your GPU a little bit of heat :D
apr. ~150-160C
If the machine will work after that you know your GPU is dead

threads.message:
best solution for chime no video
0.check if external monitior works
1.use known good screen with ldvd cable
2.change lvds connector in board in precise/ precision way....
3. then you start checking pin 2,3,4 on lvds connector

threads.message: I am not sure if the board would power up those rails without the presence of a GPU chip (need expert input here) but these motherboards do have a history of GPU failures and if I had to consider which connection points fail the most are those which convey current.

threads.message: I just took L9510 off, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> was giving that 1V so there is a short to ground on the other side, right. So the GPU is fucked up, like all boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message: Remove <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> (tantalum cap) and check if short is gone, if does not, apply 0.5V with power supply on that rail and see what is getting hot (do not limit current), if you do not find anything hot go a bit high on voltage until something gets hot, of course do not pass over from 1V........

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message: The AMD is a 216-0810084 1GB, I have a board with a 216-809000 512GB, is it compatible?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message: If anyone is wondering, it should be compatible, only check page 77 of the schematic, it depends on what memory brand (Samsung/Hinnyx) and how much VRAM you have (512MB/1GB) to solder or not any other resistors (<RESISTOR>R8611</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R8612</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R8613</RESISTOR>). 216-0810084 is compatible with 216-0810005 aswell.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Vinny, post: 2926"]If anyone is wondering, it should be compatible, only check page 77 of the schematic, it depends on what memory brand (Samsung/Hinnyx) and how much VRAM you have (512MB/1GB) to solder or not any other resistors (<RESISTOR>R8611</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R8612</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R8613</RESISTOR>). 216-0810084 is compatible with 216-0810005 aswell.[/QUOTE]


216-0810084 is directly compatible with 216-0810005? No modifications necessary?

also could you please make a truth table about compatibility between 216-0810084 and 216-809000 including combinations of Vram and required resistors?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message:
You can replace 216-0810084 with 216-0810005 but it requires soldering in a resistor that I have to look up since I have not done this in over a year. Either way all of those GPUs you will find are either someone else's shit stock, fake, or reballed.

The 216-809000 used to be available with a lesser fake/bs/reballed crap rate. I actually have a spool here I will never use. Send me your address and I'll send you a few for free.

threads.message: Does it recognize the screen? That comes first before <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>. Is <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> present on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> pin 1?

Nope, 0.012v. What is required for GMUX for this? I don't know exactly how it works. <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_DATA</SIGNAL> is 3.3v, pullup resistor is OK

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no video
threads.message:
SOLVED!!!

2 resistors missing around GPU, and soldered the resistor needed to detect 1GB Samsung VRAM

This is my succesfull board repair anthem, and I dance to it:

[url]https://youtu.be/qNMzIRnXziw?t=66[/url]
